title: Definition of ALL-NATURAL
description: being or composed of ingredients that are from nature and not artificial... See the full definition
cleaned_text: : being or composed of ingredients that are from nature and not artificial a bakery that uses all-natural ingredients Example Sentences Recent Examples on the Web One of the standout features of Fab CBD dog treats is their commitment to using all-natural ingredients. —Amber Smith, Discover Magazine, 31 Aug. 2023 It's made from merino wool and an all-natural, super sustainable Tencel material (made from eucalyptus) that works to wick away moisture (read: sweat). —Katherine Alex Beaven, Travel + Leisure, 31 Aug. 2023 This helpful, all-natural cream mixes a number of oils that ticks and bugs hate, like cedarwood, spearmint, lemongrass, and rosemary, offering relief and protection for up to four hours. —Steven Rowe, Health, 28 Aug. 2023 The non-alcoholic, all-natural drink is made with pumpkin, cinnamon, ginger, turmeric and water to refresh your dog. —Gabe Hauari, USA TODAY, 24 Aug. 2023 Sunscreen, bug spray, after sun lotion, hand sanitizer, shampoo, conditioner, and soap — all with all-natural ingredients — are included in the room. —Elizabeth Rhodes, Travel + Leisure, 23 Aug. 2023 In addition to scrubs, Glam Body also offers its spa product kit, which includes a nourishing body gel, hydrating all-natural body butter, an exfoliating body butter, detoxing bath salt and an anti-aging glaze. —Jasmine Browley, Essence, 17 Aug. 2023 Their all-natural and vegan-friendly products have gained popularity among pet owners who seek safe and effective solutions for their furry companions. —Amber Smith, Discover Magazine, 17 Aug. 2023 Ingredients 1 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips 1/2 cup smooth peanut butter (not all-natural) 2 Tbsp. —Sheri Castle, Southern Living, 17 Aug. 2023 [See More](javascript:void(0)) These examples are programmatically compiled from various online sources to illustrate current usage of the word 'all-natural.' Any opinions expressed in the examples do not represent those of Merriam-Webster or its editors.
